We are deeply grateful for the urgent and extensive assistance we are receiving from multiple government agencies and deep-sea companies as we seek to reestablish contact with the submersible. We pray for the safe return of the crew and passengers, and we will provide updates as they are available.”
Related Link Enhancement : Titanic Tourist Sub Still Missing as Rescuers Race Against Time (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2023-06-20/titanic-tourist-submersible-missing-for-third-day-with-five-aboard)If the vessel is on or near the surface of the ocean, a rescue mission would be relatively straightforward. But if the submersible is deep underwater, a rescue becomes much more difficult. Officials said they are working to find equipment that could be used for such a mission.

Several of the people in the vessel have been identified so far. They include Hamish Harding, a British businessman, the British-Pakistani businessman Shahzada Dawood and his son Suleman, and Paul-Henri Nargeolet, a French maritime expert.

The Titanic sank in 1912 after hitting an iceberg during its first voyage from Britain to New York. It killed about 1,500 people. The wreckage was discovered in 1985.

Label: Rogan, Musk, RFK Jr.: COVID-19 Vaccine Misinformation Thrives Even as Coronavirus Levels Fall (230620news.vaccines) (3,166 PV)
Subject Tags: Coronavirus, Twitter
Body:
COVID-19 levels in the U.S. may be down to near record-lows, but vaccine misinformation is thriving, with the latest example targeting a prominent scientist who said that so-called “anti-vaxxers” harassed him at home.
Related Link Enhancement : How Many Americans Will Take a Fall COVID-19 Booster Shot? (https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2023-06-16/how-many-americans-will-take-a-fall-covid-19-booster-shot)Dr. Peter Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine and a professor of pediatrics and molecular virology and microbiology at Baylor College of Medicine, tweeted that he was “stalked in front of my home” by people taunting him to debate Democratic presidential candidate and notorious vaccine skeptic Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

Hotez, who this year authored a book called “The Deadly Rise of Anti-Science” became a target of widespread online harassment after tweeting in support of a Vice article critical of a podcast that prominently featured the talking points of anti-vaxxers – or those who are skeptical of the coronavirus shot and, frequently, all vaccines.

The episode, titled "Spotify Has Stopped Even Sort of Trying to Stem Joe Rogan's Vaccine Misinformation," included Kennedy highlighting conspiracy theories related to the coronavirus shots.

Rogan, whose podcast heavy in right-leaning cultural commentary often tops the charts of the Spotify platform that hosts his program, tweeted in response: “Peter, if you claim what RFKjr is saying is 'misinformation' I am offering you $100,000.00 to the charity of your choice if you're willing to debate him on my show with no time limit.”
Cartoon Gallery : Cartoons on Donald Trump's Indictment (230404cartoons.trumpindictment) (479 PV)Billionaire industrialist Elon Musk, who frequently peddles in conspiracy theories and misinformation, waded into the conversation, saying that Hotez was “afraid of public debate because he knows he's wrong.”

Hotez offered to go on Rogan’s podcast and said he was open to doing something with Musk on Twitter – the social media platform he bought in 2022 and which of late has reintegrated voices that had been banned under prior ownership because of their amplification of questionable material.

Science is not “something that is typically debated like say 18th enlightenment philosophy or political issues," Hotez tweeted.

Hotez said the harassment he has received has been “overwhelming.”

"The attacks from the anti-vaccine lobby do come in waves. And this time, though, it's been one of the tougher ones. Because, as you pointed out, the physical stalking and the incessant threatening emails," Hotez told MSNBC on Sunday.

"And the stuff online is just total whack-a-doodle. And let's face it, when you have RFK Jr. and Joe Rogan and Elon Musk, all tag-teaming, those tres hombres at the same time," Hotez added. "That probably includes just about every follower on Twitter. So, it's pretty overwhelming."
Related Link Enhancement : Update Likely Coming for COVID Shots (https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2023-06-15/fda-committee-oks-change-to-covid-19-vaccines-ahead-of-fall-booster-campaign)The Food and Drug Administration has repeatedly published data showing that the benefits of the coronavirus vaccines overwhelmingly outweigh the risks. But the internet firestorm highlights that vaccine misinformation is becoming increasingly mainstream with no signs of slowing down.

It comes as Meta, which runs Facebook and Instagram, has decided to roll back some of its COVID-19 misinformation measures, resulting in increased worry from public health experts about the spread of disinformation.

Experts say that, despite COVID-19 cases, deaths and hospitalizations declining, misinformation hasn’t ceased.

"We haven't even reached the midpoint of the year and there's still the potential for a winter surge," Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of California, San Francisco, told ABC News. "So I'm worried that this fuel of misinformation, and the megaphone of misinformation, is going to threaten how we deal with not just COVID but all respiratory viruses this particular season."

The rise in hate speech and harassment have led some public health experts to leave platforms like Twitter.

Hotez tweeted that he will “still make an effort to remain on Twitter, in the hope that it might rebound.”
combined:

Label: Best Children's Hospitals 2023-2024 Honor Roll and Overview (230621bch.overview) (68,559 PV)
Subject Tags: family health, children's health, children, parenting, patient advice, teens, hospitals, cancer, heart health, urology, patients, pediatric cardiology
Body:
The annual U.S. News Best Children's Hospitals rankings, now in their 17th year, offer guidance to parents seeking the best place for their very sick child. The top 50 medical centers are ranked in 10 specialties, including pediatric cancer, pediatric cardiology and heart surgery and pediatric orthopedics.

Image : 230615_BCHCTScan_Stock (Right Aligned)
In the 2023-2024 rankings, 89 hospitals ranked among the best in at least one pediatric medical specialty. Ten of those hospitals earned a place on the U.S. News Best Children's Hospitals Honor Roll by garnering points for being highly ranked in many specialties.

U.S. News: Best Children's Hospitals Honor Roll


  1. Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.
  2. Boston Children's Hospital.
  3. Texas Children's Hospital, Houston.
  4. Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.
  5. Children's National Hospital, Washington, D.C.
  6. Nationwide Children's Hospital, Columbus, Ohio.
  7. Children's Hospital Los Angeles.
  8. UPMC Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.
  9. Rady Children's Hospital, San Diego, California.
  10. Johns Hopkins Children's Center, Baltimore, Maryland.

Regional Rankings


To help families identify high-quality pediatric centers close to home, U.S. News also ranked children's hospitals in each state and in seven multi-state regions. The multi-state regions, and the No. 1 hospital in each region, are:

  • Pacific: Children's Hospital Los Angeles.
  • Rocky Mountain: Children's Hospital Colorado, Aurora.
  • Southwest: Texas Children's Hospital, Houston.
  • Southeast: Children's Healthcare of Atlanta; Duke Children's Hospital and Health Center, Durham; and Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt, Nashville (three-way tie).
  • Midwest: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.
  • Mid-Atlantic: Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.
  • New England: Boston Children's Hospital.

How U.S. News Produced the Rankings

The 2023-2024 Best Children's Hospitals rankings were created from data collected through a clinical survey sent to nearly 200 hospitals and a survey sent to thousands of pediatric doctors nationwide. RTI International, a North Carolina-based research and consulting firm that also generates the Best Hospitals rankings, administered both surveys and analyzed the results. More than 100 pediatric medical experts provided input on what information to collect and how to analyze the data.

Whether and how high a hospital was ranked depended on how well it performed in three broad arenas of quality:

  • Clinical outcomes, such as maximizing survival following complex surgery, minimizing complications from kidney biopsies and preventing infections in the neonatal intensive care unit.
  • Efficient coordination of care as demonstrated, for example, by complying with accepted hand-washing protocols and other best practices, and a demonstrated commitment to advancing equity, diversity and inclusion among patients and hospital staff.
  • Providing care-related resources, such as ample nursing staff and outpatient programs tailored to particular conditions.

Each of these three major areas determined about one-third of a hospital's score in each specialty.

Results from the survey of pediatric specialists contributed up to 10% of a hospital's score, depending on specialty. Doctors were asked to name up to 10 hospitals they consider best in their specialty for children with serious or difficult medical problems. More than 5,000 physicians responded this year. Their responses were combined with those from similar surveys conducted in 2022 and 2021.

How U.S. News analyzed the data and put it together is fully described in the Best Children's Hospitals Methodology Report, available as a downloadable PDF.

The Top-Ranked Children's Hospital in Each Specialty


See complete rankings in all 10 pediatric specialties.

  • Cancer: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.
  • Cardiology & Heart Surgery: Texas Children's Hospital, Houston.
  • Diabetes & Endocrinology: Boston Children's Hospital and Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center (tie).
  • Gastroenterology & GI Surgery: Boston Children's Hospital.
  • Neonatology: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.
  • Nephrology: Texas Children's Hospital.
  • Neurology & Neurosurgery: Boston Children's Hospital.
  • Orthopedics: Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.
  • Pulmonology & Lung Surgery: Texas Children's Hospital.
  • Urology: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.

U.S. News also evaluates hospitals that treat adults, publishing rankings or ratings for 15 adult specialties and procedures and conditions such as hip replacement and heart failure.

Label: Best Hospitals for Children With Severe Congenital Heart Disease 2023-2024 (230621bch.congenitalheartdisease) (542 PV)
Subject Tags: hospitals, health, patients, children's health, congenital heart disease, heart surgery, pediatric cardiology, children, doctors
Authors: Ben Harder, Richard Nigro, Anne Pusey Roberts
Body:
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Truncus arteriosus. Terms like these speak volumes to the parents of children with severe congenital heart defects.
Image : 230615_DoctorChildBadge_Stock (Right Aligned)Heart defects occur in about 1 in 100 babies, or about 40,000 U.S. newborns per year. While any such problem can be terrifying, the surgeries required for the most severe defects are particularly risky, and the road to a healthy childhood is especially long.

Some hospitals have more experience than others in treating the most severe forms of congenital heart disease, and those are where many parents turn if their child needs a high-risk operation. Studies show the more experience a hospital and its surgical team have in performing high-risk operations, the better outcomes tend to be.

To help this subset of CHD parents identify a hospital that may be best for their child, U.S. News compiled a list of 33 hospitals that meet the following two criteria.

Each medical center listed:
  • Earned a top-50 ranking in the 2023-2024 Best Hospitals for Pediatric Cardiology & Heart Surgery rankings.
  • And scored high or very high for the number of high-risk pediatric heart surgeries it has handled, which means it performed at least 150 such operations.

Each hospital's corresponding ranking among the top 50 Best Hospitals for Pediatric Cardiology & Heart Surgery is also shown in the left-hand column below to provide parents with context.

33 Best Hospitals for Children With Severe Congenital Heart Disease

Label: U.S. Teens’ Reading and Math Scores Feature Largest Declines Ever (230621news.tests) (949 PV)
Subject Tags: K-12 education, education, standardized tests, testing
Body:
At a moment when teachers, principals, school superintendents, education policy experts and parents hoped to see signs of a turnaround in the academic performance of U.S. students after successive years of severe declines in the wake of the pandemic, more bad news: The latest federal data shows basic math and reading skills further tumble among 13-year-olds this school year.
Related Link Enhancement : Illinois Becomes First State to Ban Book Bans (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-13/illinois-becomes-first-state-to-ban-book-bans)The average scores for 13-year-olds declined 4 points in reading and 9 points in math compared to the previous assessment administered during the 2019-20 school year. The math decline marks the single largest decline observed in the last half century on the exam. Compared to when the test was administered a decade ago, the average scores declined 7 points in reading and 14 points in mathematics.

“The green shoots of academic recovery that we had hoped to see have not materialized, as we continue to see worrisome signs about student achievement and well-being more than two years after most students returned for in-person learning,” said Peggy Carr, commissioner of the National Center for Education Statistics, the Education Department’s research arm, which administered the test.

“There are signs of risk for a generation of learners in the data,” Carr said on a press call with reporters on Tuesday. “We are observing steep drops in achievement, troubling shifts in reading habits and other factors that affect achievement, and rising mental health challenges alongside alarming changes in school climate.”

The new scores mirror declines observed in other national tests administered by NCES, including the math and reading exams given to fourth- and eighth-grade students, also known as the “Nation’s Report Card,” especially the major drops in math. Another common theme that held true in the newest assessment data: Scores declined for all student subgroups, including gender, race and geographic location. But students who already performed the worst saw some of the biggest declines.
Cartoon Gallery : Cartoons on Donald Trump's Indictment (230404cartoons.trumpindictment) (479 PV)The math scores for the lowest performing students returned to levels last seen in the 1970s, and the reading score for lowest performing students was actually lower than it was the very first year these data was collected, in 1971.

“If you were expecting to see something different in terms of signs of recovery,” Carr said, “well these don't show something very different. What we may be seeing here though is that the learning disruption further undermined the development of basic skills that students need at this age, particularly the lower performing students.”

The test was administered this school year, from October through December, and was given to 13-year-olds, most of whom were in eighth grade. At the onset of the pandemic, most of the students were 10. The release of the achievement data marks the final in a series of federal efforts to track the academic impact of COVID-19.

In addition to testing students on basic math and reading concepts, the assessment also surveyed students on their learning experiences in and out of the classroom. Roughly one-third of 13-year-olds said they “never or hardly ever” read for fun, for example, compared to 22% who said the same a decade ago. And just 24% reported taking algebra compared to 34% who reported taking it a decade ago.

“The big message here,” Carr said, “is that there is a long road ahead of us.”

Education Secretary Miguel Cardona echoed that sentiment in a statement, saying that the results are evidence of what the Biden administration has known since Day one – “that the pandemic would have a devastating impact on students’ learning across the country and that it would take years of effort and investment to reverse the damage.”

Though encouraged by a trickle of states beginning to report state-specific math and reading achievement that matches pre-pandemic levels, Cardona said that “this latest data reminds us how far we still need to go.”
combined:
Title: U.S. Teens’ Reading and Math Scores Feature Largest Declines Ever (230621news.tests) (949 PV); Content: At a moment when teachers, principals, school superintendents, education policy experts and parents hoped to see signs of a turnaround in the academic performance of U.S. students after successive years of severe declines in the wake of the pandemic, more bad news: The latest federal data shows basic math and reading skills further tumble among 13-year-olds this school year.
Related Link Enhancement : Illinois Becomes First State to Ban Book Bans (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-13/illinois-becomes-first-state-to-ban-book-bans)The average scores for 13-year-olds declined 4 points in reading and 9 points in math compared to the previous assessment administered during the 2019-20 school year. The math decline marks the single largest decline observed in the last half century on the exam. Compared to when the test was administered a decade ago, the average scores declined 7 points in reading and 14 points in mathematics.

“The green shoots of academic recovery that we had hoped to see have not materialized, as we continue to see worrisome signs about student achievement and well-being more than two years after most students returned for in-person learning,” said Peggy Carr, commissioner of the National Center for Education Statistics, the Education Department’s research arm, which administered the test.

“There are signs of risk for a generation of learners in the data,” Carr said on a press call with reporters on Tuesday. “We are observing steep drops in achievement, troubling shifts in reading habits and other factors that affect achievement, and rising mental health challenges alongside alarming changes in school climate.”

The new scores mirror declines observed in other national tests administered by NCES, including the math and reading exams given to fourth- and eighth-grade students, also known as the “Nation’s Report Card,” especially the major drops in math. Another common theme that held true in the newest assessment data: Scores declined for all student subgroups, including gender, race and geographic location. But students who already performed the worst saw some of the biggest declines.
Cartoon Gallery : Cartoons on Donald Trump's Indictment (230404cartoons.trumpindictment) (479 PV)The math scores for the lowest performing students returned to levels last seen in the 1970s, and the reading score for lowest performing students was actually lower than it was the very first year these data was collected, in 1971.

“If you were expecting to see something different in terms of signs of recovery,” Carr said, “well these don't show something very different. What we may be seeing here though is that the learning disruption further undermined the development of basic skills that students need at this age, particularly the lower performing students.”

The test was administered this school year, from October through December, and was given to 13-year-olds, most of whom were in eighth grade. At the onset of the pandemic, most of the students were 10. The release of the achievement data marks the final in a series of federal efforts to track the academic impact of COVID-19.

In addition to testing students on basic math and reading concepts, the assessment also surveyed students on their learning experiences in and out of the classroom. Roughly one-third of 13-year-olds said they “never or hardly ever” read for fun, for example, compared to 22% who said the same a decade ago. And just 24% reported taking algebra compared to 34% who reported taking it a decade ago.

“The big message here,” Carr said, “is that there is a long road ahead of us.”

Education Secretary Miguel Cardona echoed that sentiment in a statement, saying that the results are evidence of what the Biden administration has known since Day one – “that the pandemic would have a devastating impact on students’ learning across the country and that it would take years of effort and investment to reverse the damage.”

Though encouraged by a trickle of states beginning to report state-specific math and reading achievement that matches pre-pandemic levels, Cardona said that “this latest data reminds us how far we still need to go.”

Label: Powell to Congress: Taming Inflation Has a ‘Long Way to Go,’ More Rate Hikes Likely (230621news.powell) (407 PV)
Subject Tags: inflation, Federal Reserve, Powell, Jerome, economy
Body:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell tried to walk a fine line Wednesday in the first of two days of congressional testimony between explaining why the central bank paused its interest rate hikes while also acknowledging that inflation is far higher than it desires.
Related Link Enhancement : Fed’s Powell to Testify to Congress (https://www.usnews.com/news/economy/articles/2023-06-20/feds-powell-to-testify-to-congress-as-new-housing-construction-surges)The Fed put a hold on its aggressive campaign of raising interest rates for what would have been the 11th straight time, saying it wanted to digest the effects of a series of hikes that have lifted borrowing costs by 5% since March 2022. At the same time, more than half the members of the Federal Open Market Committee said they expected to have to raise rates two more times this year.

“Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year,” Powell told members of the House Financial Services Committee in his opening remarks. “Nonetheless, inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go.”

Republican committee Chairman Patrick McHenry of North Carolina told Powell to continue his resolve in fighting inflation, blasting Democrats for irresponsibly stimulating the economy during the pandemic and laying the foundation for the worst inflation in 40 years.

“Clearly our economy is in a precarious position,” from rising rates, tighter credit conditions and inflation, McHenry said.
Cartoon Gallery : Political Cartoons on Inflation in the U.S. (230509cartoons.inflation) (26 PV)California Democrat Maxine Waters, the ranking member, lauded the Fed for putting a hold on interest rates and warned that the strong growth in the labor market seen in the past couple of years would be threatened by more interest rate hikes. She cited the Inflation Reduction Act, passed by Democrats nearly a year ago, with helping to bring down the rate of consumer inflation from 9.1% last year to 4% in May.

Waters also took a swipe at Republicans, who she said were more concerned with gas stoves than they are with improving the banking system and holding bank executives accountable.

Powell noted the Fed’s actions to date in raising rates, but added: “We have raised our policy interest rate by 5 percentage points since early last year and have continued to reduce our securities holdings at a brisk pace.”

“We have been seeing the effects of our policy tightening on demand in the most interest rate-sensitive sectors of the economy,” Powell said. “It will take time, however, for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation.”

In response to a question from McHenry, Powell said that “given how far we’ve come, it may make sense to move rates higher but at a more moderate pace.”

Stocks have run up in recent weeks on expectations the Fed was nearing an inflection point but have taken their own pause this week awaiting Powell’s testimony and a clearer sense of where the economy is headed.
Related Link Enhancement : Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged – For Now (https://www.usnews.com/news/economy/articles/2023-06-14/fed-leaves-interest-rates-unchanged-for-now-signals-more-rate-hikes-to-come)“Periods of economic regime shifts are difficult for policymakers to manage,” Jeffrey Roach, chief economist, and Lawrence Gillum, chief fixed income strategist for LPL Financial, said on Tuesday. “This current environment could be eerily similar to early 2007, when the Fed held a tightening bias on rates as they believed the housing market was stabilizing, the economy would continue to expand, and inflation risks remained.”

“Both the January 2007 statement and the most recent one last week specifically mention the FOMC’s process in determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be needed,” they added. “Clearly, those expectations were not met since we know what happened in later quarters. Despite the reference to 2007, our baseline is that the economic slowdown does not produce another ‘2008,’ yet investors should anticipate some volatility as the economic outlook remains cloudy.”

In particular, while there are signs the economy has slowed, the labor market still remains extremely tight by historical standards and the housing market seems to be showing new signs of life.

Some economists are now backing off their predictions of an imminent recession, the common result of a Fed tightening cycle and diminished economic growth. But there remain headwinds, notably less availability of credit and inflation that is eating into consumer pocketbooks.

“In this unique business cycle defined by unusual labor market characteristics, there is scope for hope that the US economy could escape a recession,” EY Parthenon Chief Economist Gregory Daco wrote Wednesday morning.

“Indeed, unlike in prior downturns, business executives have proven reticent to dispose of the pool of talent they struggled to hire, train, and retain post-pandemic,” he added. “This labor hoarding phenomenon has so far translated into a limited drag on household income and, as a result, a gradual consumer spending slowdown rather than a retrenchment.”
combined:

Label: When Is Amazon Prime Day? (220127_whenisamazonprimeday) (20 PV)
Subject Tags: shopping
Body:
Forget the Fourth of July and Labor Day – the most anticipated shopping holiday of the summer is Amazon Prime Day. The online retailer's two-day shopping event that comes around every summer, Prime Day offers major discounts, deals, and limited-time flash sales for Amazon Prime members.

Sales aren’t limited to Amazon devices and products either. Shoppers can find Prime Day deals on a range of products, including TVs, laptops, gadgets, and so much more across the site.

Here’s what you should know about Amazon Prime Day – when it is, how it works, and what you should buy. But before you begin shopping, check out these Amazon coupons for possible extra savings on a variety of products.

When Is Amazon Prime Day?

Amazon Prime Day is set for July 11-12, 2023. You'll have 48 hours to shop some of the best deals available on the site until the holiday season. The event started in July 2015 and was only 24 hours long, but it's been two days long since 2019. Fortunately, if you happen to miss the designated sale days, there will still be deals on Amazon throughout the week.

Last year, Amazon introduced a second two-day sale event called Prime Early Access Sale, which took place Oct. 11-12. The event was similar to Prime Day and was meant to help shoppers get a head start on their holiday shopping. The Prime Early Access Sale may return this year, but we won't know for sure until Amazon announces it later in the year.

What Is Amazon Prime Day? 

Amazon Prime Day is an annual two-day sale that takes place on amazon.com. It started in 2015 as a single-day sale to celebrate the online retailer’s 20th birthday and boost revenue during the summer slump in sales. Since then, Prime Day has grown to a nearly week-long event with millions of discounts on everything from Fire TV sticks to coffee makers.

Last year was the biggest Prime Day yet with more than 300 million items purchased and more than $1.7 billion saved by shoppers – the most savings of any prior year, according to Amazon. The most popular items fell into these categories: Amazon devices, consumer electronics, and home products.

The discounts are only available to Amazon Prime members, so you’ll need to sign up for a Prime membership to access the exclusive deals.

If you don’t have a Prime membership, you can still score major discounts on Prime Day at other retailers. The sale has become quite popular, so other retailers like Walmart, Target, and Macy's now offer their own sales during Prime Day to compete with Amazon.

What Do I Need To Do To Shop on Amazon Prime Day? 

To take advantage of this year’s Amazon Prime Day deals, you must be an Amazon Prime member. It costs $14.99 per month or $139 per year for a regular membership, and $7.49 per month or $69 per year for students. Prime memberships also include dozens of perks, such as access to exclusive movies and TV shows on Prime Video, free two-, one-, and same-day delivery on qualifying items, and more.

Shoppers who aren't Prime members can sign up for a free 30-day trial membership. This will give you access to Prime Day deals without having to pay the monthly or annual membership fee, so long as you cancel the membership before the trial ends. A student Amazon Prime free trial lasts six months.

More Deals To Save

  • This Week's Best Deals
  • Best Apple Deals
  • Best TV Deals
  • Best Laptop Deals
  • Best Vacuum Deals

  • How Does DoorDash Work?

Why You Can Trust Us

Label: China Blasts ‘Absurd’ Biden Reference to Xi as Ill-Informed ‘Dictator’ (230621news.china) (623 PV)
Subject Tags: China, Biden, Joe, Blinken, Antony, world news
Body:
President Xi Jingping’s government on Wednesday professed outrage at President Joe Biden’s dismissive reference to China’s leader as a “dictator” at a fundraising event late Tuesday – an apparent attempt to gain a rhetorical edge over Beijing.
Related Link Enhancement : General Warns of India-China Clashes (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-03-31/top-general-warns-of-concerning-chinese-activities-along-border-with-india)“It is a blatant provocation. China expresses strong dissatisfaction and opposition,” Mao Ning, a spokeswoman for China’s Foreign Ministry, told reporters early Wednesday. “The U.S. remarks are extremely absurd and irresponsible.”

Speaking at a campaign fundraiser in California on Tuesday evening, Biden mocked what he framed as Xi’s ignorance about the circumstances leading up to a potential international crisis earlier this year when a Chinese spy balloon drifted across North America before a fighter jet shot it down off the coast of South Carolina.

“The reason why Xi Jinping got very upset in terms of when I shot that balloon down with two boxcars full of spy equipment in it is he didn’t know it was there,” Biden said.

“That’s what’s a great embarrassment for dictators – when they didn’t know what happened,” he added. “That wasn’t supposed to be going where it was. It was blown off course up through Alaska and then down through the United States. And he didn’t know about it. When it got shot down, he was very embarrassed.”
Cartoon Gallery : Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong Un, Emmanuel Macron and More: Political Cartoons on World Leaders (190306cartoons.worldleaders) (2,270 PV)Biden did not explain the source of the assertions, which appear to be based on U.S. intelligence assessments of the aftermath of the balloon incident.

What was ostensibly a passing jibe from the 2024 Democratic presidential candidate is widely seen as an attempt to burnish his tough-on-China credentials days after Secretary of State Antony Blinken traveled to Beijing and met with Xi to slow the steady deterioration of relations between the world’s two largest powers. The rhetoric will all but certainly continue to heat up as Biden positions himself for reelection against a challenger from the Republican Party, which has consistently criticized his handling of Chinese economic and military aggression.

China has likewise attempted to portray the high-profile summit with the visiting diplomat as an example of U.S. acquiescence – a narrative Biden’s domestic political rivals, too, are eager to embrace.

Republicans have widely condemned the optics of Blinken’s trip, including imagery China has widely proliferated showing the chief U.S. diplomat sitting at a table in a grand meeting room listening to Xi, seated at the head and conspicuously higher up. Chinese state media has also drawn subtle attention to the fact the meeting took place on Father’s Day, suggesting that Beijing is moving toward a paternal relationship with America.

Blinken himself balked at questions on Tuesday when asked if the U.S. president sees his Chinese counterpart as an equal.

“I’m not quite sure how to take that question,” Blinken said from London, where he was traveling for a meeting with Ukraine’s international benefactors about reconstruction for the war-torn country. “President Xi is the leader of China and, in and of itself, that makes him someone of tremendous significance on the world stage.”
Related Link Enhancement : China’s Growing Influence as an International Mediator (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-03-16/chinas-growing-influence-as-an-international-mediator)Aside from the balloon flap earlier this year, the summit also came amid reports China is investing heavily in new military and intelligence presences in Cuba – details first reported by The Wall Street Journal that the White House has subsequently downplayed as a potential threat it has already begun to address.

“China is trying to improve their global reach and influence and, again, their global intelligence collection capabilities,” John Kirby, a spokesman for the National Security Council, told reporters on a teleconference this week. “It's not like we aren't aware of it, it's not like we haven't been monitoring it and, quite frankly, it's not like we haven't taken steps and will continue to take steps to thwart it.”

Rep. Mike McCaul, Texas Republican and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, blasted the summit as wasteful and said the Biden administration’s latest overtures to the Chinese Communist Party are deeply concerning and effectively toothless.

“Blinken brushing off the recent CCP spy balloon that traversed the U.S. was ridiculous and totally dismissive of the concerns of the American people,” the Texas Republican said in a statement in which also lamented what he considered Blinken’s inability to address other issues such as climate change, fentanyl imports to Mexico or returning Americans detained in China. “And just as troubling – China’s recent agreement with Cuba to house a CCP military training facility was not addressed during these meetings.
combined:

Label: Poll: Republicans Prioritize Principles Over Electability Ahead of ‘24 (230621news.gop) (292 PV)
Subject Tags: Republican Party, elections, presidential elections, polls, voters, Biden, Joe
Body:
Republicans really want to beat President Joe Biden in 2024. But the rank-and-file voters in the party aren't making that a priority when deciding whom to pick as the presidential nominee, according to a poll released Wednesday.
Related Link Enhancement : Poll: Majority Wants Trump to Drop Out (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-16/poll-majority-says-trump-should-drop-out-of-presidential-race)The Marist Institute of Public Opinion found that 63% of Republicans and GOP-leaning independent voters believe it is more important to nominate someone who stands on conservative principles, while 35% said it's more important to pick someone who can defeat Biden.

"Republicans want their party to stay true to its core, conservative principles," Lee Miringoff, director of the nonpartisan Marist Institute, said in a statement. "Electability may emerge as an important factor down the road when the nominees for both parties are in place. But right now, it’s not Republicans’ top priority."

That's positive news for former President Donald Trump, who leads in national polls and most statewide polls for the Republican nomination. While other surveys have shown increasing voter concern over Trump's second indictment, a 37-count series of felony charges involving his handling of classified and other government documents, the Marist poll suggests his devoted base is sticking with him.
Cartoon Gallery : Cartoons on the 2024 Presidential Election (230501cartoons.2024elections) (101 PV)In fact, while both Marist last week and CNN on Tuesday released polling showing that most voters believe the indictment means Trump should get out of the race, Wednesday's Marist survey found that Trump's standing has grown among GOP voters. More than three-fourths (76%) of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents have a positive view of Trump, the Wednesday poll found, up from 68% who reported feeling that way in February.

The poll is also potentially good news for Biden, who appears likely to secure the Democratic nomination again despite rank-and-file concerns about the 80-year-old president's age. Biden has cast himself as the Democrat most able to beat Trump, noting that he’s done it once before.

Several polls over the past months show that overall, voters do not want to see another Biden-Trump face-off, but even Democratic voters who didn't want the president to run again will support him anyway.

An NBC poll in April, for example, found that 51% of Democrats didn't want Biden as the nominee, but 88% of Democrats said they would definitely or probably vote for him regardless of the fact that he is not their first choice.

For Biden, there is less of a choice, since the incumbent vastly overshadows his primary opponents, in terms of both visibility and fundraising, and enjoys formal party backing.
Related Link Enhancement : Just Another Day on the Campaign Trail (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-13/trump-treats-arraignment-as-another-day-on-the-campaign-trail)For Trump, the question is more complicated. While he enjoys the advantages of being a former president – including the fundraising donor lists and the loyal support of a core group of voters who believe he was cheated out of the 2020 win – Trump has a pack of GOP primary foes waiting for him to fall.

The former president is well ahead of his competitors in polls, and the devotion of his base means he could be the GOP field’s strongest candidate against Biden. But his standing could plummet if and when his legal situation worsens.

Trump's criminal trial in New York is scheduled for March 25 – a critical point in the primary season – and a Florida judge set Aug. 14 as the trial date for the government documents case against him (though legal experts believe the trial will be delayed).

Should Trump fall, one of his opponents could try to take the conservative mantle. But only two of Trump's GOP primary challengers – Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and Sen. Tim Scott of South Carolina – have approval ratings above 50% among Republican voters, Marist found.

DeSantis, who is running a distant second to Trump in primary polls, has an approval rating of 67% among Republicans, Marist found, while Scott has a favorability rating of 50%. For now, the nomination appears to be Trump's to lose.
combined:

Label: Search for Titanic Tourist Submersible Ramps Up After Underwater Noises Heard (230621news.titanic) (715 PV)
Subject Tags: oceans, Coast Guard
Body:
The U.S. Coast Guard on Wednesday said it is bringing in additional search vessels after a Canadian airplane detected underwater noises during the search for a missing submersible carrying five people to look at the wreckage of the Titanic in the Atlantic Ocean.
Related Link Enhancement : Search for Titanic Tour Sub Intensifies (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-06-20/search-intensifies-for-missing-titanic-tourist-submersible)Data on the noises is so far “inconclusive,” officials said during a press briefing on Wednesday.

“We need to have hope, but I can’t tell you what the noises are,” Capt. Jamie Frederick of the U.S. Coast Guard said.

The noises were detected on Tuesday and Wednesday, he said. But officials cautioned that many things could make such noises – including undersea animals.

“We don’t know what they are, to be frank with you,” Frederick said, adding that they are searching in the area where the noises were detected.
Photo Gallery : Photos You Should See - June 2023 (230606gallery.june23_pyss) (1,328 PV)The search mission, which now covers a surface area that is two times the size of Connecticut, is “incredibly complex,” according to Frederick.

The submersible, named “Titan,” went missing on Sunday and may have less than a day’s worth of oxygen left. Frederick said the vessel is carrying limited rations of food and water as well.

The five people on board the Titan are a British adventurer, two members of a Pakistani business family and a French maritime expert along with pilot Stockton Rush, the CEO of the OceanGate Expeditions company that runs the trips.
Related Link Enhancement : Missing Titanic Sub: When It Vanished and the Race to Find It (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2023-06-21/missing-titanic-sub-when-it-vanished-and-the-race-to-find-it)If the vessel is on or near the surface of the ocean, a rescue mission would be relatively straightforward. But if the submersible is deep underwater, a rescue becomes much more difficult. Officials are working to find equipment that could be used for such a mission.

The Titanic sank in 1912 after hitting an iceberg during its first voyage from Britain to New York, killing about 1,500 people. The wreckage was discovered at a depth of about 12,500 feet – or more than 2 miles – below the surface in 1985.

Frederick did not speculate as to when the search may end.

“Sometimes you’re in a position where you have to make a tough decision,” he said. “We’re not there yet.”
combined:

Label: Hunter Biden’s Questionable Case of ‘Special Treatment’ (230621news.hunter) (251 PV)
Subject Tags: Biden, Hunter, Biden, Joe, taxes, courts
Body:
Republicans called Hunter Biden's plea agreement on tax and gun-related charges a "sweetheart deal," a "traffic ticket" punishment a less-connected American would not have been offered.

And the president's son may well have gotten special treatment – but not in a good way, tax lawyers and former prosecutors say.

"The tax charges that were filed are not normally tax charges that we would have recommended at the Justice Department. We just don't prioritize failure to file, with a relatively low dollar amount and no sign or evidence of evasion, or an effort to conceal" a scheme to avoid paying taxes, says Brian Galle, a former prosecutor of tax crimes at the Department of Justice.

"By traditional Justice Department criteria, we wouldn't have charged this case," adds Galle, a professor at Georgetown Law. "Mr. Biden's kind of getting worse treatment than a typical defendant would get."

Prominent tax attorney Eric Green notes that "there are more than 10 million non-filers" across the country, but the vast majority are not criminally prosecuted, since it would take an enormous commitment of government resources to take them all to court.

Being famous or politically connected can work against a tax violator, Green and others say, since the government likes to showcase someone whose case will end up in the news. The tax system relies heavily on widespread public compliance, and those stories provide a grim reminder to the less-famous that not paying your taxes can land you in jail. Celebrities, including actor Wesley Snipes, singer Lauryn Hill and baseball player Darryl Strawberry, were sentenced to time behind bars for tax crimes.

"They can't prosecute everyone, so they want to make an example out of people," says tax lawyer Daniel Ryan, a partner at Boston-based Sullivan & Worcester who once worked as an attorney in the IRS's chief counsel's office. The message is, "Look what happened to this guy – it could happen to you," Ryan says.

And with Biden, the Justice Department has an added pressure to prosecute, says Green, a partner at Green & Sklarz in Connecticut. "They have a hostile Republican Congress who's calling for his head. They've indicted Trump. It looks very political if they don't do anything. I think that in some ways, he is getting it worse."

Biden agreed to a plea deal Tuesday for "willful" failure to pay taxes for two years and for failure to note on paperwork for a gun purchase that he had abused drugs. The tax charges, which are misdemeanors, are expected to result in a penalty of probation. The gun-related infraction – based on a law a Texas court has deemed unconstitutional – is expected to be dropped if Biden meets certain, yet unspecified, conditions.

The coming plea has infuriated Republicans, who are vowing to continue their own investigation of both Hunter and President Joe Biden. Hunter Biden, a lawyer and former lobbyist, was on the board of Ukrainian energy company Burisma Holdings when his father was vice president and has done business in China and elsewhere.

Republicans insist there is a deeper scandal, one involving bribes to the elder Biden through his son's business dealings. But aside from Hunter Biden's obvious asset of being related to the then-vice president, GOP investigators have yet to show any criminal connection to the elder Biden.

Republicans had hoped that the five-year Justice Department investigation would produce something more damning about Hunter Biden, or at least a more serious punishment. They claim the department has a double standard, indicting Trump on charges that could well result in prison time while letting Hunter Biden go free.

David Weiss, the prosecutor who led the investigation of Hunter Biden, was appointed by Trump.
Cartoon Gallery : Political Cartoons on President Joe Biden (190816cartoons.joebiden) (1,939 PV)The Trump and Hunter Biden cases are dramatically different: Trump, after all, is accused of not only wrongly possessing classified and other government documents but refusing to give them back even after a subpoena and a search of his home by the FBI. The younger Biden, experts say, could theoretically have faced prison time, but it would have been very unusual for someone in his tax situation.

"I would have argued for probably a year and a half" for someone who owed $200,000, as the Weiss statement said the younger Biden failed to pay, says Boston lawyer Evan Gotlob, a former assistant U.S. attorney who handled public corruption and white-collar crime investigations.

But in cases where Justice might seek 12-18 months behind bars, "it kind of makes sense to plead it out" anyway, since "it's not worth the resources to go to trial," adds Gotlob, now a partner with Saul Ewing.

But unlike other celebrities who indeed went to jail, the younger Biden was not charged with tax evasion but rather a misdemeanor, experts note. Tax evasion, generally speaking, is committed when someone schemes and defrauds to avoid paying taxes, often involving others and spanning several tax years, explains Keith Rosen, former chief of the criminal division for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Delaware.

If someone merely fails to pay taxes – even when he or she knew it was required by law – the infraction is a misdemeanor. says Rosen, now at the global law firm of Norton Rose Fulbright.

"If you look at the statistics, you would find that those [misdemeanor charges] are frequently offenses that don't result in prison. The Justice Department is not in the business – and the IRS is not in the business – of regularly charging people with misdemeanor tax offenses," Rosen adds.

As for the gun charge, people typically aren't prosecuted for it unless it's part of some other illegal conduct or if the defendant has a criminal history, Rosen says.

"I'm not surprised there was a settlement. Settlements in regard to tax matters are relatively common," says Eric Chaffee, a law professor at Case Western University School of Law.

"With the election coming up relatively soon, it only benefits the Biden camp if the Hunter Biden matter is put behind them. There was an incentive to get a settlement, and these things are relatively common. But this is not a common case," since it involves the president's son, he adds. Republicans, meanwhile, are determined to keep the matter alive and in the public eye.
combined:

Label: Rape Kit Backlogs Remain in States Despite Funding (230620bs.kits) (267 PV)
Subject Tags: sexual assault, rape, Department of Justice, crime
Body:
Untested rape kits have piled up in law enforcement facilities and crime labs across the United States, according to nonpartisan data center USAFacts.

A recent report from the nonprofit found that despite Justice Department funding totaling over $1.3 billion since 2011 for programs that contain a focus on clearing backlogs of untested kits, many states have struggled to do so, leaving cases unresolved. Across 30 states and Washington, D.C., USAFacts found at least 25,000 kits in need of testing in 2022.

Rape kits are collected through highly invasive medical examinations with victims of rape or sexual assault, and can last several hours. Typically, kits are sent through law enforcement agencies to be logged as evidence, and then on to forensic labs for testing. But throughout this process, they can end up in a backlog with law enforcement or at the crime lab.

As USAFacts notes, the Justice Department has provided funds to reduce accumulated kits through programs such as the DNA Capacity Enhancement for Backlog Reduction and the National Sexual Assault Kit Initiative. But the organization’s analysis indicates limited success.

Through either a request for information or publicly available reports, USAFacts was able to obtain data from 18 states regarding law enforcement backlogs and from 22 states and the District of Columbia regarding crime lab backlogs.

In the case of law enforcement, Connecticut has maintained no backlog since 2018, while Alaska reported no remaining kits in law enforcement agencies that hadn’t been submitted to a crime lab and New Hampshire had just one unsubmitted kit by the end of 2022. North Carolina was able to reduce its number of untested kits from over 15,000 at the end of 2018 to just 113 by the end of 2022 – a reduction of over 99%. Washington was able to cut its backlog by over 90%, going from 5,855 kits to 585 over the same time period.

[ EXPLORE: Read the USAFacts Report ]

Other states did not see such success. Maryland and Massachusetts had among the largest reported law enforcement backlogs in the country in recent years: Massachusetts managed to reduce its total by only 7% between 2021 and 2022 – the only years for which data for the state was available – while Maryland’s ultimately increased by 10% from 2018 to 2022. Louisiana and Oregon – the latter of which declared a backlog of old kits cleared in 2018 – saw backlogs increase by over 35% between 2018 and 2022, with Texas seeing a 45% increase between 2021 and 2022.

Raw HTML : Number of Untested Kits in State Backlogs, 2018-2022
Meanwhile, in North Carolina’s case, the sheer volume of the more than 15,000 kits sent from law enforcement to crime labs may have ended up backing up the labs tasked with testing them.

By the end of 2022, North Carolina crime labs had over 9,000 kits that had not been tested for at least 30 days. Four other states – Oregon, West Virginia, Louisiana and North Dakota – saw their crime lab backlogs grow by a factor of five or more in that time frame. Overall, just 10 of 20 states that reported crime lab backlogs of any size at some point between 2018 and 2021 had reduced them by 2022.

Notably, some states provided data to USAFacts with different thresholds for a backlog. While the organization requested the number of kits that had been awaiting testing for at least 30 days, Texas provided figures for kits that had gone without testing for 90 days or more. Pennsylvania’s data consisted of kits waiting for more than a year.

Though the total number of backlogged rape kits nationwide is unknown, USAFacts points to a 2022 report from the Congressional Research Service that cited estimates running as high as 400,000 kits unsubmitted to laboratories for the period 2014 to 2018.

As for why the issue persists, the Joyful Heart Foundation’s End the Backlog initiative points to deficiencies in policies and protocols, training, and resources, stating that it costs on average between $1,000 and $1,500 to test a single rape kit. A 2015 report funded by the Department of Justice on unsubmitted kits in Detroit also pointed to victim-blaming among law enforcement personnel as contributing to decisions not to submit kits for testing.

In recent years, survivors in Houston and Memphis have filed lawsuits against officials in relation to untested kits; survivors also have brought suits contesting law enforcement practices in sexual assault investigations.

Some legislators, too, are searching for answers when it comes to kit backlogs. In February, bipartisan members of Congress introduced legislation to reauthorize funding for clearing backlogs, though it remains in committee. States such as Wisconsin and Mississippi have recently approved legislation establishing time requirements for rape kit procedures. And earlier this month, Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards signed a bill into law establishing a new tracking system to address his state’s backlog.

Read USAFacts’ methodology here.

If you are seeking information or guidance regarding sexual assault, resources and information are available here.
combined:
